instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Works well but not recognizing USB devices
threads.message:
Hello,

I have another macbook that had liquid damage that I repaired, it had a short to ground under <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, as well as a damaged J3300 which I replaced both of making it boot and operate as normal.

The only item that does not work properly is that the device will not recognize or show a USB flash drive that I plugged in, it will provide some power to the USB flash drive as indicated by a faint glow on the LED inside the flash drive, but otherwise there is no response to the drive. I tested several other drives to make sure it wasn't the USB drive that was unresponsive.

I have replaced PI3USB32224BXEAE twice from two donor boards, but still have the same effect of no response from the computer when a USB is plugged in.

Are there other chips that manage USB connectivity other than PI3USB32224BXEAE and <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Works well but not recognizing USB devices
threads.message:
Check if you get 5V on the USB device.
Did you try another USB-C hub?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Works well but not recognizing USB devices
threads.message:
I only have access to the one USB-C Hub, but it works on my primary macbook.

When working on my primary MacBook, the Flash drive pulls 5.04v, 0.09a

When plugged into the non-working USB MacBook the drive pulls, 5.08v, 0.0007a or 0.7ma

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Works well but not recognizing USB devices
threads.message:
Check if problem persists in USB 2.0 and 3.0 modes.
Use a mouse for USB 2.0 test.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Works well but not recognizing USB devices
threads.message:
So I tested using USB 2.0 and 3.0 using both a mouse and a flash drive and it seems like initially they are fully powered for 0.1 second (lights are at full brightness for both the mouse and the flash drive) but then nearly immediately dim (the flash drive) or the light goes out completely and is unresponsive (the mouse)

So it seems like they can be fully powered, its just power is being cut to them almost immediately after being plugged in

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Works well but not recognizing USB devices
threads.message:
Confirm if USB device loss power.
5V output is going through <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>; both ports have same behavior?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Works well but not recognizing USB devices
threads.message:
Immediately after plugging in the USB flash drive the ammeter jumps to 5.01v 0.0554amp for about 0.5 seconds then goes back down to 5.01v 0.0007 amps, 

Same behavior on both ports

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a Works well but not recognizing USB devices
threads.message:
So USB power is maintained.
In this case you have problems with data lines.
Check diode mode and voltage; compare with good board.

Also check continuity from USB terminals to corresponding points on the MLB.
Maybe some resistors got broken, or knocked off in J3300 area.
There are also many protection diodes.
